items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. February is a good time to start growing late spring transplants and quick-maturing crops in a greenhouse, even in regions with cold and snowy winters.

2. Greenhouses come in different types - modular plastic, low tunnels, cold frames, and designer greenhouses. The type determines the level of temperature control and protection provided.

3. Good crops to grow in a greenhouse in February include tomatoes, peppers, brassicas (kale, cabbage, cauliflower), lettuces, potatoes, onions, and various flowers.

4. Greenhouse growing helps provide a head start on the growing season, protects plants from pests and diseases, and allows for growing cool-weather crops like brassicas and lettuces even in frost-free areas.

5. Key factors to consider are maintaining consistent warmth (50¬∞F or higher), moisture, and light for optimal growth of seedlings and transplants.

6. Greenhouses with more advanced features like heating, ventilation, and climate control allow for year-round growing of a wider range of crops.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 01/30/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The key points from the agricultural news article are:

Corn and soybean futures saw record highs in 2025, with corn reaching $8.50 per bushel and soybeans reaching $18 per bushel. This was driven by strong demand and reduced global supplies due to adverse weather conditions.

In response, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced a $5 billion aid package for farmers in December 2025. This included direct payments of up to $100,000 per farmer to help offset increased input costs.

The Renewable Fuels Association reported that ethanol production reached an all-time high of 17 billion gallons in 2025, up 8% from the previous year. This was driven by the Biden administration's push for greater biofuel blending.

Looking ahead, the USDA is projecting corn and soybean yields to rebound in 2026, with corn yields forecast at 180 bushels per acre and soybean yields at 50 bushels per acre. This is expected to help ease pressure on commodity prices.

Farmers are encouraged to review risk management strategies such as crop insurance and forward contracting to protect against price volatility in the year ahead.

items.title: Cotton Wholesalers Protect Demand Across Diverse Retail Channels
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – Cotton wholesalers help preserve broad-based demand by serving retail channels that would [...]
items.summary:
Key points:

- Cotton wholesalers serve independent stores, regional chains, uniform programs, and workwear accounts that lack the scale or capital to buy directly from factories. 

- Wholesalers break large production runs into smaller, manageable assortments and replenishment programs that keep these outlets viable.

- Wholesalers also democratize access to compliance, traceability, and quality standards, raising overall market discipline while reducing the burden on individual retailers.

- Without wholesalers, assortments would narrow, buying would become more conservative, and out-of-stocks would increase. This would reduce cotton's retail footprint and concentrate demand among fewer players, increasing vulnerability across the supply chain.

- The article emphasizes that wholesale distribution helps sustain the diversity of cotton demand.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference
items.description: Kansas City, MO., (January 28, 2026) ‚Äì  The Packer, the produce industry‚Äôs premier publication from Farm Journal, announced the launch of The Avocado Conference, a first-of-its-kind international event gathering every segment of the U.S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. The conference directly […] The post Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board are launching "The Avocado Conference", a first-of-its-kind international event for the U.S. avocado supply chain.

2. The inaugural event is scheduled for November 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront.

3. The conference directly supports the Hass Avocado Board's (HAB) mission to strengthen the global avocado industry and make Hass avocados America's preferred healthy food.

4. The conference aims to serve as a premier forum for collaboration, data-driven insights, supply-and-demand analysis, and strategic industry alignment among producers, exporters, importers, packers, retail and foodservice buyers, and other supply-chain partners.

5. The program will cover global avocado production and trade, differentiated retail and foodservice market insights, consumer and shopper trends, evolving avocado marketing programs, economic and investment dynamics, and the Hass Avocado Board's efforts to expand avocado demand.

6. Stakeholders attending the event will include growers, packers and shippers, importers and exporters, retail and foodservice buyers, input suppliers, logistics and packaging companies, storage and ripening professionals, financial and consulting services, and data and insights providers.

7. The Hass Avocado Board is collaborating on the content development and will play a critical role in uniting the avocado industry for this event.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. The updated training manuals, including the Iowa Core Manual (CS445), are now available for purchase through the ISU Extension Store. New exams based on the revised core manual are available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. Additionally, the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1) now includes a two-page informational update, and all private exams now include content from this insert. Farmers can contact Betsy Danielson, the Pesticide Safety Education Extension Specialist, at betsydan@iastate.edu for more information.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should be about delivering real value to farmers in exchange for their time and attention, not just capturing leads.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer you choose shape how many leads are captured, and how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects are.
- Shifting the mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need is crucial for designing the right offer.

There are no specific numbers, prices, dates, or expert quotes provided in the article. The article is focused on a general marketing strategy recommendation for businesses targeting farmers.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Temperatures this week in Illinois were 4-8 degrees below normal, with lows reaching -5¬∞F in Rockford and -2¬∞F in Aurora. Strong winds led to wind chills near -20¬∞F on some days.

- Precipitation has been very low, with the first two-thirds of January being the 4th driest on record in Carbondale and 10th driest in Charleston, both receiving less than 0.5 inches.

- The cold weather is expected to continue for at least another week, with most of northern Illinois likely staying below freezing for the rest of the month.

- A strong winter storm is forecast to bring significant snowfall of 8-12 inches to areas south of Interstate 64 in Illinois this weekend, with 3-4 inches expected in central Illinois.

- The WILL radio programs "Commodity Week" and "Closing Market Report" discussed the weather and market conditions with experts Chip Nellinger, Brian Stark, and Arlan Suderman.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Instead, the emphasis is now on building brand authority and trust through "answer engine optimization" (AEO) strategies.

Key points:
- Farmers are increasingly using AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews to find information, moving away from traditional search engines.
- Ag marketers need to adapt their strategies to be present and credible in these new discovery channels, or they risk becoming invisible to their target audience.
- At Farm Journal, the focus is on developing an "answer-driven content strategy" and amplifying trusted voices to improve discoverability across various platforms.
- Discoverability is no longer just about winning the click; it's about winning citations, brand mentions, and establishing the brand as a trusted source, even in "zero-click" moments.

The article suggests that ag marketers need to reevaluate their 2026 strategies to align with these changes in how farmers discover and consume information.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Forest farming, also known as multi-story cropping or agroforestry, refers to farming within treed land. It originated in Brazil's tropical rainforests.

- Benefits include improved water and soil quality, increased carbon storage, and a diversity of specialty crops like mushrooms, syrups, and edible roots.

- Ideal for farms with existing forest or riparian areas surrounded by trees. Doesn't require a large-scale operation - even small farms with some forest can benefit.

- Before starting, inventory natural resources, manage invasive trees, and develop a forest management plan. Consult local ag extension and forestry agencies.

- Consider market opportunities beyond farmer's markets and restaurants, like mail order, pick-your-own, and direct market associations.

- Regulations around wild plants may apply, so check CITES guidelines.

- Overall, forest farming can seamlessly integrate the farm into the landscape and diversify farm products in an ecologically beneficial way.

items.title: Jan 16 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: The second week of the year brought a fleeting taste of spring, with average temperatures between the mid-30s to upper 40s; 8 to 12 degrees above normal. Some of the more impressive daytime high temperatures this week included 69 in Kaskaskia and 68 in Carbondale. January to date has been 7 to 12 degrees above normal statewide, and has been a top 10 warmest first half of January on record in most parts of the state.…
items.summary:
Daytime highs reached 69¬∞F in Kaskaskia and 68¬∞F in Carbondale. However, precipitation was light, with just 0.1-0.75 inches over the past 7 days. Most of the state has been 0.5-1 inch drier than normal so far this winter, with southern Illinois experiencing a top 5 driest winter on record.

This warm, dry weather will come to an end this weekend as much colder air moves in. Highs will struggle to reach 20¬∞F in northern Illinois and above freezing in the south, with lows in the single digits on Monday. Little precipitation is expected, just light, intermittent snow. Colder than normal temperatures are forecast to continue through the first week of February.

The article also includes updates on WILL's Commodity Week and Closing Market Report radio programs, which feature market analysis from experts like Logan Kimmel, Jim McCormick, and Mike Zuzolo.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
Spray drones can provide flexibility, reduce field traffic, and improve access to difficult areas. However, adopting the technology requires careful consideration of regulations, training, insurance, and management practices.

Key points:
- Spray drones can be useful for applications when soils are wet, applying to tall crops, reducing compaction, and supplementing existing spraying capacity.
- Regulatory requirements include an FAA Part 107 remote pilot certificate, FAA Part 137 certification for aerial pesticide application, and IDALS licensing. A 2-day Part 107 training workshop is scheduled for February 24-25, 2026 in Ames, IA.
- Specialized insurance is required, including chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage coverage. 
- Equipment selection factors include spray tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, and GPS capabilities.
- Proper training on safe operation, calibration, and weather monitoring is essential.
- Farmers are encouraged to start with small acreage trials before full adoption.
- Iowa State University, IDALS, and industry partners offer educational resources to support spray drone use.

The article recommends a gradual, cautious approach to adopting spray drone technology in Iowa, utilizing available educational and regulatory guidance.

items.title: Double-crop Soybean Management Practices – Project Report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction There is a growing interest in wheat/soybean double-cropping systems in Illinois, extending into parts of central Illinois where wheat acreage has been limited in recent decades. USDA-NASS survey estimates that 60-80% of Illinois wheat acres are double-cropped with soybeans. Implementing this system in central and northern Illinois has been constrained primarily by low wheat acreage and by later wheat harvest, which often delay
items.summary:
Key Findings:

1. Double-crop soybean yield averaged 55.7 bushels/acre in 2024 and 47.8 bushels/acre in 2025 in Piatt County, Illinois.

2. Full-season soybean varieties (MG 3.6-3.8) yielded about 4% (2.1 bushels/acre) more than early-maturing varieties (MG 3.0-3.2), across seeding rates and fertility treatments.

3. Yield response to seeding rate differed by soybean maturity group:
   - Early-maturing varieties reached maximum yield (52.3 bu/acre) at about 252,000 seeds/acre.
   - Full-season varieties reached maximum yield (53.4 bu/acre) at about 207,000 seeds/acre.

4. Starter fertilizer (N+S) increased double-crop soybean yield by 1.4 bushels/acre (2.6%) in 2024, but had no impact in 2025 or on average.

5. This research was supported by the Illinois Agricultural Experiment Station, Illinois Fertilizer & Chemical Association, and a local producer.

6. The findings are considered preliminary, and similar trials across years and locations are ongoing to strengthen regional recommendations.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Vegetables:
- Cabbages (standard, Napa, and 'Carex' short-maturity varieties) - hardy Brassicas that can handle cold weather
- Spinach - varieties like 'Avon' and 'Space' that resist mildew and bolting
- Onions (long-day, short-day, and intermediate-day types) - take advantage of their long maturation period
- Leafy greens like kale, collards, chard, watercress, and microgreens - highly nutritious and fast-growing

Flowers:
- Pansies - hardy, cold-loving flowers that make great cut flowers and bedding plants
- Echinacea - important for integrated pest management, and needs cold stratification 
- Snapdragons - 4 groups to choose from based on climate, do well with winter sowing
- Larkspur/Delphinium - provide rare true-blue color and attract pollinators
- Scabiosa - attract beneficial insects and work well for fresh and dried arrangements

The winter sowing method involves starting seeds in protected containers outdoors, allowing the cold, moist conditions to help break seed dormancy. This results in hardier transplants that mature faster than direct sown seeds.

items.title: 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss
items.description: On today‚Äôs farms, ecologically-friendly practices are on the rise. Using agri-environmental strategies, farmers prevent environmental degradation, preserving natural spaces and the species that live in them. The post 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
However, there are several agri-environmental strategies farmers can employ to support biodiversity:

1. Plant prairie strips - Devoting 10-25% of farmland to prairie strips can boost yields, improve soil nutrients, and attract beneficial predators and pollinators. The diverse plants and flowers support a healthy above and below-ground ecosystem.

2. Reduce tilling and use cover crops - Minimizing tillage and planting cover crops instead improves soil structure and increases insect biodiversity. This supports more animal species on the land.

3. Practice regenerative grazing - Using a rotational grazing model and planting native grasses/forbs instead of non-native forage can boost biodiversity in grazing areas, especially when combined with techniques like prescribed burning and silvopasture.

4. Implement Integrated Pest Management (IPM) - Attracting beneficial insects through diverse plantings and cultural pest control methods reduces the need for harmful pesticides that damage biodiversity.

5. Establish conservation easements - Partnering with land trusts to protect farmland can provide more habitat for local species while also offering tax benefits to landowners.

Adopting these strategies, even partially, can help farmers work in harmony with the natural world around them, supporting species diversity and overall farm health. Experts emphasize that these practices, while sometimes requiring more effort upfront, ultimately lead to more sustainable and productive agricultural systems.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. The meetings will feature topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists. 

Key details:
- Dates and locations: Jan 6 - Sioux Center, Jan 7 - Storm Lake, Jan 8 - Burlington, Jan 9 - Mason City, Jan 13 - Estherville, Jan 15 - Waterloo, Jan 16 - Davenport, Jan 21 - Ankeny, Jan 22 - Atlantic, Jan 27 - Iowa City, Jan 28 - Le Mars, Jan 29 - Carroll
- Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, late/on-site is $100
- Registration includes refreshments, lunch, CCA credits, and access to resources
- Private pesticide applicator recertification available for a $30 fee
- Registration and more info at the Crop Advantage Series registration site
- Contact crops@iastate.edu or your regional ISU Extension agronomist for questions

The goal is to provide farmers and crop professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season. Topics will include crop outlooks, nitrates, nutrient management, pests, transition planning, and precision agriculture.

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
The finalists are Alsum Farms (Friesland, Wisconsin), Dalton Farms (Wakeman, Ohio), and Splitter Farms (Sterling, Kansas). These outstanding producers are being recognized for their excellence, leadership, and innovation in modern agriculture. 

The 2026 Top Producer Summit, agriculture's premier executive-level conference, will be held on February 9-11, 2026 in Nashville, Tennessee. At the event, the Top Producer of the Year winner and finalists will be formally recognized, along with the Next Generation Award winner, Tim Nuss (El Dorado Hills/Lodi, California), and the Women in Agriculture Award winner, Helle Ruddenklau (Amity, Oregon).

Alsum Farms is a multigenerational family operation producing potatoes, pumpkins, hay, and other rotational crops across over 3,600 acres. Dalton Farms is a seventh-generation family farm with 2,000 acres of corn and soybeans, a 400-head cattle herd, and a growing on-farm market. Splitter Farms is a Kansas row-crop operation spanning 1,400 owned acres and 18,500 total farmed acres, led by Matt and Janna Splitter.

The 2026 Top Producer of the Year award is sponsored by BASF and Fendt. The Next Generation Award is sponsored by Pioneer and Fendt, and the Women in Agriculture Award is sponsored by Pro Farmer.

items.title: Still an opportunity to attend the ICM Conference!
items.description: This year we are offering on-site registration for the Integrated Crop Managem
items.summary:
The Integrated Crop Management (ICM) Conference is being held on December 10-11, 2025 at the Meadows Events and Conference Center in Altoona, Iowa. The conference offers:

items.title: Registration is now open for the 36th Integrated Crop Management Conference
items.description:
Join us for the 36th Integrated Crop Management Conference, which brings together a range of topics related to crop production, crop protection, nutrient management, and soil and water management. The event features experts sharing research updates and practical recommendations. Don‚Äôt miss this key opportunity for networking and education!

Where: The Meadows Events Center in Altoona, Iowa

Who
items.summary:
The conference features 33 session topics and is open to anyone involved in crop production. Early-bird registration is $260 until November 16, after which regular registration is $310 until December 3. 

The conference offers networking opportunities, education from expert speakers, and the chance for commercial pesticide applicators to earn recertification credits in categories 1A, 1B, 1C, and 4. items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10, 2024, at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5, 2024.

The event will feature research on the value of sorghum as a forage crop, highlighting its drought tolerance, lower nitrogen requirements, and lack of a host relationship with the tar spot pathogen, compared to corn. 

Speakers will include Mitch Tuinstra, the Wickersham Chair of Excellence in Agricultural Research and scientific director of the Institute for Plant Sciences at Purdue, who will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality. Other speakers include Brad Shelton, FPAC superintendent; Jason Tower, Southern Indiana Purdue Agricultural Center superintendent; Nick Minton, Purdue Extension beef systems specialist; and Jeff Jackson, Croplan alfalfa and forage specialist.

The event will offer venue tours from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm, and a dinner with a bull test station tour from 5-6 pm.

Those interested in attending should register by September 5, 2024, and contact Brad Shelton at sheltonb@purdue.edu with any questions or accessibility needs.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024, with the Purdue/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rising 8 points to 113.

- The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.

- This positive shift was attributed to fewer respondents reporting worsened conditions compared to a year ago and a decrease in those expecting negative future outcomes.

- High input costs remained the biggest concern for 34% of farmers, while 29% cited the risk of lower crop and livestock prices, up from 25% in June.

- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points in July to 81, 6 points lower than in July 2023, reflecting farmers' worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.

- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points in July to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than in July 2023.

- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118 from 115 in June, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146.

- 72% of crop farmer respondents expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same as in 2024, with 15% anticipating a rise and 13% expecting a decline.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn:

- Tar spot fungal disease has been endemic in Latin American countries since 1904 but was not detected in the U.S. prior to 2015. Since then, it has spread to 16 states and Ontario, Canada by 2022.

- Purdue researchers, led by C.D. Cruz, are using a mix of statistical, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, AI, and computer vision methods to better understand the dynamics of tar spot in corn. Their work is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million.

- In previous efforts, the researchers developed a digital method (SCDA) to quantify tar spot in corn, which they tested against human raters. They are now refining the training methods to improve the model's accuracy.

- The research team also includes Purdue's Mohammad Jahanshahi, who has adapted his AI and computer-vision approaches to inspecting and analyzing civil infrastructure damage for agriculture.

- Graduate students Mariela Fern√°ndez-Campos and Abhishek Subedi are finalizing a proof-of-concept data fusion project, integrating drone imagery and weather data to capture details about the tar spot pathosystem.

- Another parallel task is to quantify and model tar spot epidemics in production-style fields, using disease observations and drone-based imagery.

- The interdisciplinary approach aims to quantify and model tar spot severity by referencing and integrating imagery with spatial and temporal data.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
Key events and details:
- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique will be open throughout the fair, offering wool products, clothing, jewelry, and more.
- On August 2 at 10 a.m., there will be open wool judging and a wool sale in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion.
- The Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show will be held on August 4 at 2 p.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- The Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest will take place on August 4 at 5 p.m. in the Ball State University Champions Pavilion.
- From August 8-11, fairgoers can sample free Indiana lamb at the Taste from Indiana Farms event in the Indiana Farm Bureau Fall Creek Pavilion.
- The annual Sheep to Shawl competition, where youth teams create a wool shawl from scratch, will be held on August 18 at 10 a.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.

In addition, sheep can be found in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion from August 4-20 for open and 4-H shows. The overall theme for ISA's participation is "Art and Nature," featuring artwork by Indiana artists depicting sheep.

The Indiana Sheep Association was originally founded in 1876 as the Indiana Wool Growers Association. The IN S&W program collects 0.5% of the net market price of each sheep sold in Indiana to support educational, promotional, and research efforts involving sheep.

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.
items.summary:
Purdue Extension will have a presence at the fair, offering interactive demonstrations and activities at the Purdue Extension Building. Activities will include a Block Party for young children, a Book Party focusing on math skills, and the Captain Cash program to teach financial management. Visitors can also engage with Purdue Extension experts in fields like entomology, human health, forestry, and animal sciences.

On August 7, the Purdue Food Science Department will host an interactive exhibit called "What's Growing on My Spinach?" where fairgoers can plate bacteria from spinach leaves and observe microbial growth. They will also offer samples of "Cricket Rice Krispies Treats" and share information about alternative proteins and the use of insects as a food ingredient. The Food Entrepreneurship and Manufacturing Institute will distribute samples of Boilermaker Hot Sauce developed by Purdue students.

Seed art displays will be featured in livestock barns and the Purdue Extension Building, visually representing the fair's theme and providing information about animal diets and nutrition. The Pioneer Village will also offer antique tractors, a farm toy show, a fiddler's contest, and other 1800s-themed activities sponsored by the Purdue Ag Alumni Association.

Purdue Extension exhibits will be located throughout the fairgrounds, including the 4-H Exhibit Hall, 4-H Centennial Hall, and other pavilions. Purdue University is a public research institution ranked among the top 10 public universities in the United States, with a commitment to affordability and accessibility.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary:
The new Potassium Cycle publication from the University of Wisconsin-Madison's Nutrient and Pest Management (NPM) program provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication outlines key potassium concepts, including:

- Potassium sources and sinks in the soil
- Potassium uptake and removal by common Wisconsin crops
- Factors affecting potassium availability and plant utilization
- Recommended potassium application rates and timing for optimal crop production

The publication is designed to help Wisconsin farmers better understand the potassium cycle and make informed decisions about potassium management in their cropping systems. It is available for free download from the NPM program's website.
